content.title: Holographic Bound: Maximum Information in a Region of Space
content.abstract: A worked example calculating the holographic bound on information content for various physical systems, from human brains to black holes to the observable universe, demonstrating how Planck area sets the fundamental information limit.
content.problem_statement: Calculate the maximum information (in bits) that can be contained in: (a) a human brain, (b) a stellar-mass black hole, and (c) the observable universe, using the holographic bound S_max ≤ A/(4ℓ_P²).

formulas.bekenstein_bound: S ≤ 2πk_B ER/(ℏc) (original form for energy E, radius R)
formulas.bits_conversion: I_max = S_max/k_B ln(2) = A/(4ℓ_P² ln(2)) bits

step_1.title: Calculate Surface Area
step_1.note: Real brain has larger surface area due to folding, but we use envelope

step_2.title: Calculate Holographic Bound
step_2.interpretation: Maximum ~10⁶⁸ bits can fit in a brain-sized volume

step_3.title: Compare to Actual Brain Capacity
step_3.actual: Human brain: ~10¹⁵ synapses × ~10⁴ bits/synapse ≈ 10¹⁹ bits (generous estimate)
step_3.interpretation: We use only 10⁻⁴⁹ of the holographic limit—room for ~10⁴⁹ more brains' worth!

part_b.title: Stellar-Mass Black Hole (M = 10 M_☉, R = r_s = 30 km)

step_1.title: Calculate Schwarzschild Radius
step_1.note: For black hole, holographic bound is SATURATED (equality holds)

step_2.title: Calculate Horizon Area
step_2.interpretation: Event horizon has area of ~10¹⁰ m² (roughly 1/4 of Netherlands)

step_3.title: Calculate Bekenstein-Hawking Entropy
step_3.interpretation: 10 solar mass black hole holds ~10⁷⁹ bits of information

step_4.title: Compare to Pre-Collapse Star
step_4.interpretation: Gravitational collapse increases information capacity 10²⁰ times!

step_1.title: Calculate Cosmic Horizon Area
step_1.note: Using particle horizon radius ~ 46 billion light-years

step_3.title: Compare to Actual Entropy
step_3.interpretation: Universe uses only 10⁻¹⁸ of holographic capacity

step_4.title: Future Maximum
step_4.if_collapsed: If all matter collapsed to single black hole: S → 10¹²¹ bits
step_4.approach_limit: Would approach but not exceed holographic bound
step_4.note: de Sitter horizon limits final state entropy

scaling_law.formula: I_max ∝ R² (scales with area, not volume!)
scaling_law.interpretation: Information capacity grows as surface, not interior—holographic!
scaling_law.implication: Interior degrees of freedom are 'projected' onto boundary

physical_meaning.statement: The holographic bound says physics is really 2D encoded, appearing 3D
physical_meaning.black_holes: Black holes saturate the bound—maximum density of information
physical_meaning.non_black_holes: Ordinary matter vastly underutilizes available information capacity

information_paradox_connection.question: When matter falls into black hole, where does information go?
information_paradox_connection.holographic_answer: Encoded on horizon; Hawking radiation carries it out
information_paradox_connection.status: Still debated; firewall, ER=EPR, and other proposals

cosmological_implications.cosmic_information: Total cosmic information ~10¹⁰⁴ bits, mostly in black holes
cosmological_implications.future: As universe expands, horizon area grows, increasing maximum
cosmological_implications.heat_death: Final state: de Sitter horizon with maximum S ~ 10¹²² bits

key_results: Holographic bound: I_max = A/(4ℓ_P² ln(2)) bits
Information scales with area, not volume—holographic!

prerequisites.title: Planck Area Definition
prerequisites.reason: ℓ_P² is the quantum of area

sources.citation: Bekenstein, J.D. (1981): Universal upper bound on the entropy-to-energy ratio for bounded systems, Phys. Rev. D 23, 287
Bousso, R. (2002): The holographic principle, Reviews of Modern Physics 74, 825

validation.notes: Holographic bound formulas validated. Universe entropy estimate from Egan & Lineweaver. All calculations verified.

learning_objectives: Apply holographic bound formula to various systems
Compare actual information to maximum capacity
Understand scaling with area vs volume
Recognize black holes as maximum entropy objects
